EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: Yes. So this father was deployed for ten months. He came home and he surprised his son in Tennessee.

Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You are such a big boy. I am so proud of you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: That is so sweet, indeed.

All right. Set your . Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

"SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hey, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Hey, Dana.

Sometimes I feel man slapped but it's OK.

President Trump says the worst may be yet to come for Venezuela's embattled and disputed government.

Democrats are proposing big changes for the U.S. Supreme Court, the Electoral College, and the nation's voting age.

And we take you for an exclusive look at the front lines in Syria as U.S.-backed forces engage ISIS in the terror group's last stand.

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening. I'm Bret Baier. We're coming to you live tonight from the White House where I will talk with one of the president's top economic advisors in just a few minutes.

We begin though with President Trump saying all options are still on the table in the effort to remove Venezuela's disputed president and his socialist government. The American leader saying here in the rose garden even stronger sanctions may be coming. He spoke with reporters this afternoon alongside the visiting Brazilian president.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts was there. Good evening, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. And a lovely afternoon in the rose garden it was.

So far the effort to oust Venezuelan dictator Nicolas Maduro has been unsuccessful. There had been some cracks in his regime but so far none big enough to wedge him out.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: Venezuela was Topic A in President Trump's first meeting with the new Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro. President Trump indicating he has no idea when Nicolas Maduro may step down if ever.

TRUMP: I'm not being told any specific time but we really haven't done the really tough sanctions yet, we can do the tough sanctions and all options are open.

ROBERTS: Brazil shares a border with Venezuela and has been assisting the U.S. in getting humanitarian aid to Venezuelans fleeing economic collapse. Bolsonaro indicated he may allow U.S. troops to base out of Brazil if the need for military action arises.

JAIR BOLSONARO, BRAZILIAN PRESIDENT (through translator): Brazil would be more than willing and ready to fulfill this mission and take freedom and democracy to that country.

ROBERTS: In welcoming Bolsonaro to the White House President Trump was almost looking in the mirror. Bolsonaro is known as the Trump of the Tropics. He has the same views as the President on immigration, uses Twitter as a megaphone --

BOLSONARO: fake news.

ROBERTS: -- and decries fake news.

TRUMP: we're going to have a fantastic working relationship. We have many views that are similar.

ROBERTS: Bolsonaro also represents a break from a long line of anti-U.S. leaders promising a new relationship with America on everything from trade to energy to military cooperation. President Trump is happy to embrace the change.

TRUMP: I also intend to designate Brazil as a major non-NATO ally or even possibly, if you start thinking about it, may be a NATO ally which will greatly advance security and cooperation between our countries.

ROBERTS: In the Oval Office prior to their joint press appearance, President Trump was asked about his weekend Twitter feud with Meghan McCain after President Trump ripped her father for giving the FBI the unverified Steele dossier.

The President was unapologetic pointing to McCain's vote against repealing and replacing Obamacare.

TRUMP: So he campaigned, he told us hours before that he was going to repeal and replace and then for some reason, I think I understand the reason, he ended up going thumbs up. I think that's disgraceful. I was never a fan of John McCain and I never will be.

ROBERTS: President Trump also weighed in on Twitter and Facebook today after his director of social media was temporarily blocked on Facebook and Republican Congressman Devin Nunes filed a $250 million lawsuit against Twitter.

TRUMP: It seems to be if they're conservative. If they're Republicans, if they are in a certain group, that is discrimination, a big discrimination. I do think we have to get to the bottom of it.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: President Trump also used Bolsonaro's visit to take a swing at the emerging socialist movement in the Democratic Party here. Bolsonaro won the presidency in Brazil by campaigning against the socialist corruption that had led to Brazil's economic decline. President Trump repeated his mantra that the U.S. economy is stronger than ever and that the last thing we need is socialism -- Bret.

BAIER: Thanks -- John.

Let's get some insight on the U.S. economy and the President's big plans from the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisors, Kevin Hassett. Kevin -- thanks for being here.

KEVIN HASSETT, WHITE HOUSE COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISORS: It's good to be here.

BAIER: Your overview first of all this report just out, you seem kind of ecstatic but --

M1: Yes. I'm always ecstatic.

BAIER: -- behind that.

M1: Right. Well, I think that basically what we've done is we published a book with 700 pages that documents President Trump's policies are working, that the economy has gone from the new normal of low growth to the old normal of 3 percent growth, that it's doing it precisely because the policies are working the way economists think they should.

So we said a year ago in the fall that capital spending would working, the economy has gone from a new normal of low growth to the old normal of 3 percent growth and it's doing it precisely because the policies are working the way economists think they should.

And so we said a year ago in the fall that capitol spending would boom and that factories have come back to America. We documented that that is happening in the data.

We said when the factories would come back, that people would be hired more and so unemployment rate went down to historic lows for just about every category rate -- democratic category. And we said that wages would grow a lot because the people at the factories would be competing for workers and we see that as well.

And the most striking thing on that, you know, I promise not to filibuster is the bottom 10 percent of Americans saw wage growth last year of 6.5 percent.

BAIER: JPMorgan in their forecast for 2019 said this. "Significant U.S. economic outperformance is unlikely to persist through 2019 as the sugar rush of the fiscal stimulus wanes."

M1: Yes. So a lot of people said that we wouldn't have a sugar rush and now they're calling it a sugar rush, but it's not a sugar rush. So a sugar rush again --

(CROSSTALKING)

M1: People should we are having a sugar rush but it's not a sugar rush. People should go to a Disney. It's even like a that admits that sugar does that to you. But in any case if we ate at twinkie and a bunch of twinkies and spent all our money on twinkies. The next would bad and we wouldn't have any money and we'd be sorry when we did that.

What happened now is that we didn't, you know eat Twinkies. We took vitamins and we made the economy stronger exercise and it's stronger from now on.

And so people built more factories last year, that made the GDP go up because they're buying machines. This year though, factories are turning on and they're going to make output and that's going to make GDP go up again. So it's the opposite of a sugar rush.

BAIER: For the folks who are critical about the next steps -- like what are the next steps this administration will take to try to push that growth forward?

MILLER: Well, I think the first thing is that we just have to like hold the line here. There are a lot of people who want repeal this policies that in the economic report we demonstrate worked.

But then the next thing is that there's a lot of stuff that we could do without Congress in the deregulation states, we have a whole chapter documenting the big impact on the economy -- positive impact of deregulation. And then there are other things that we could do that require legislation that we hope to infrastructure spending.

America's infrastructure is decaying a lot and we can fix that. And historically those kind of fixes have happen on a bipartisan basis.

BAIER: "Wall Street Journal" pointing out that some of the tax cuts expire. They have a timeline on them. They said the 2017 tax law also created temporary incentives for alcohol producers and businesses that provide family leave, both of which expire this year.

So by including revenue from expected scheduled explorations in the budget the administration sets fiscal targets in such a way that either it has to support those tax increases happening as scheduled or find replacement revenue. So which one will you do?

M1: Right. Well, in our budget, we basically assume that almost all the tax cuts are permanent and that's the way we do the math.

And so I don't know what this guy is saying but that's the way we do the math in our budget. President Trump has a whole bunch of policy objectives including things like infrastructure spending, making tax cuts permanent, getting more people into the work force by adding work requirements to some of the welfare programs.

And all of those policies are in the baseline of our assumptions in the economic report. And so if you say well, that's a rosy scenario you're saying that maybe there's going to be 3 percent growth over the next decade.

You know, I agree that it's an optimistic scenario because it's a scenario where President Trump's policies are enacted into law. If they're not enacted into law if people obstruct our ability to engage in these positive policies and for sure growth will fall short.

BAIER: The President is heading to Ohio. Sherrod Brown, the senator from Ohio has this suggestion about cars. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SENATOR SHERROD BROWN (D), OHIO: -- last week. So I've been talking to the President about this. He finally he woke up and acted like he wants to do something.

He should be going to Congress and say pass past the American Cars and American Jobs Act. Briefly, it works this way. You buy a car listed of 100 vehicles made, mostly in the United States. You buy one of those, you get a $3500 off rebate at the dealership.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: So in other words, protect U.S. automakers by giving them this rebate, something that you guys would look at?

M1: You know, I haven't spoken with the President about that specific proposal but he has been fighting and fighting and fighting since he's been here for auto workers, to move auto plants from other countries to the U.S.

And so I think the specific thing that Senator Brown, who I have a great deal of admiration for, is mentioning that there's a GM plant that's closing in Ohio that the two of them have been talking about.

I think that GM has very idiosyncratic problems. Most of the auto makers are doing great, they are expanding. A lot of, you know -- Ford is expanding and a lot of foreign manufacturers are moving production to the U.S

And so I think that, you know, we certainly want to save that plant but I think that there are idiosyncratic problems for GM. They'll require a massive new bill. President Trump has been fighting for automakers all across the board, the trade deals or the tax cuts, everything else.

BAIER: The trade deals are a big factor in how this economy looks. And you are optimistic.

M1: Yes. Yes. That's right. And Ambassador Lighthizer is continuing the talks with Secretary Mnuchin and, you know, I think, you know, I have set a couple times on the air that we are at the point where you don't want the groom to see the bride.

But you know, it's really hard to negotiate a trade deal. It's a lot of hard work and there's a lot of legalese that has to be worked out correctly and I think Ambassador Lighthizer is the guy that can lead that effort to (INAUDIBLE).

BAIER: An optimistic Kevin Hassett. Kevin -- thanks a lot.

M1: Thanks.

BAIER: I appreciate the time.

M1: Thanks for having me.

BAIER: In "America's Election Headquarters" tonight, an effort by some Democrats running for president to expand the U.S. Supreme Court, an issue that lingered on the political rim for decades has suddenly and surprisingly become a hot campaign topic on the trail.

Fox News chief legal correspondent and anchor of "FOX NEWS @ NIGHT" Shannon Bream takes a look at trying to radically change the rules for choosing our unelected justices.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

SENATOR ELIZABETH WARREN (D-MA), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: All the options are on the table.

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS CHIEF LEGAL CORRESPONDENT: Some White House wannabes are talking up a judicial redo, an effort to tap into lingering progressive anger over President Trump's two nominees for the high court -- Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh.

WARREN: When it swings back around to us what are we going to do?

BREAM: The solution FOR many Democrats? More is best, reforming who can serve and for how long. Among the proposals: rotating justices on and off the bench from the lower appellate courts and term limits for currently life tenured federal judges.

SENATOR CORY BOOKER (D-NJ), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Term limits for Supreme Court justices might be one thing, it gives every president the ability to choose three. We have people holding onto those seats in ways that I don't think is necessarily healthy.

BREAM: South Bend, Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg has his own plan.

MAYOR PETE BUTTIGIEG (D), SOUTH BEND, INDIANA: One idea that I think is interesting is you have 15 members but only ten of them are appointed in the political fashion, five of them can only be seated by a unanimous agreement of the other ten.

BREAM: The constitution does not establish a set number of justices -- that's up to Congress. There were initially six members of the high court, then five, then seven, then nine, down to eight, ten for a while, back down to eight before finally settling on nine a century and a half ago.

FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I will appoint Justices who will not undertake to override the judgment of the Congress.

BREAM: Franklin Roosevelt's audacious court packing plan in the 1930s to add up to six justices met with widespread public and political condemnation and was soon abandoned. It's no secret the other two branches have long chafed at high court rulings limiting presidential and congressional power.

So to change the decision, the thinking goes change the deciders with more choices a new Democratic president could quickly offset the current 5-4 conservative majority.

TRUMP: We would have no interest in that whatsoever. It will never happen. It won't happen. I guarantee you it won't happen for six years.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So help me God.

BREAM: Some court watchers think the current Democratic expansion tease has little chance of success.

ILYA SYAPIRO, CATO INSTITUTE: Something this controversial could be bad for the Democrats indeed in the 2020 election. If you start adding justices for purely partisan motives, that can't help but divide the country even further.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BREAM: There are prominent Democrats on the Hill cautioning their colleagues in the 2020 pack not to waste time on what they are calling a fool's errand with regards to radically making over the high court.

And while they may be split, Republicans aren't. GOP lawmakers in both the House and Senate plan to offer up measures to stop any attempt at packing the courts -- Bret.

BAIER: Shannon -- thanks. See you at 11:00.

Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren wants to get rid of the Electoral College. Warren made that comment last night during a town hall meeting in Mississippi.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

WARREN: My view is that every vote matters. And the way we can make that happen is that we can have national voting and that means get rid of the Electoral College for everybody.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Well, supporters of the Electoral College used some of that same argument saying it keeps candidates from focusing solely on major population centers where large clusters of voters live like New York and California.

Speaking of big changes, Democrats are also coming around to the idea of lowering the voting age to 16.

Senior political correspondent Mike Emanuel tells us why.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MIKE EMANUEL, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT: There's a push on the left to allow younger kids to vote in the NEXT presidential election. house Democrats try to shift the voting age in federal elections from 18 to 16.

Their argument is young people are mobilizing and pushing older Americans to action on issues ranging from gun violence to climate change.

REP. AYANNA PRESSLEY (D), MASSACHUSETS: They are at the forefront of social and legislative movements and have earned inclusion in our democracy.

Beginning at the age of 16 --

EMANUEL: Pressley's amendment failed by 179 votes but a majority of Democrats favored it.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The amendment is not adopted.

EMANUEL: And so does the House Speaker who says she has always favored lowering the voting age.

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: It's really important to capture kids when they're in high school when they're interested in all of this. When they're learning about government to be able to vote.

EMANUEL: Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell fired back there is no need to drive turnout.

SENATOR MITCH MCCONNELL (R-KY), SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: What is the problem? We had the biggest election turnout since 1966 last year. If the idea here is to make it more likely we have a higher turnout. It seems to me that's happening.

EMANUEL: And other Republicans countered Democrats are pushing it because they're convinced it would benefit them.

REP. JIM JORDAN (R), OHIO: They think more of those individuals are going to vote Democrat. They think it helps them, just like they think allowing noncitizens will help them. It's all designed to benefit Democrats and help them on Election Day.

EMANUEL: But a Fox News contributor and former DNC chair and says it does not hurt to try.

DONNA BRAZILE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: 16-year-olds, 17-year-olds are ready. They are engaged. They want to get involved. They want to have their voices heard. I think it's a great idea.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

EMANUEL: The voting age was lowered to 18 back in 1971 but it took a constitutional amendment and part of the pitch was if you are old enough to fight in the Vietnam War, you are old enough to vote. At this point there does not appear to be that kind of energy to lower it to 16 -- Bret.

BAIER: Mike -- thanks.

The Dow snapped a four day winning streak, losing 27 today. The S&P 500 fell a fraction. The Nasdaq was up nine.

The brother of the girlfriend of Amazon founder Jeff Bezos says he made a quote "deal with the devil", meaning the "National Enquirer". Michael Sanchez told Fox News media analyst Howard Kurtz he cooperated with the tabloid in its story about the affair in order to protect their relationship. Sanchez would not confirm a "Wall Street Journal" report that he was paid $200,000 for intimate texts between the two.

Up next, we take you on the ground as U.S. backed forces close in on ISIS terrorists making their last, desperate stand in Syria. First, here's what some of our Fox affiliates around the country are covering tonight.

Fox 26 in Houston as authorities say a drop in water pressure caused a large fire at a petro-chemicals terminal to intensify overnight and spread to additional storage tanks. Authorities said the fire could continue to burn for at least another day. Students return to classes today nearby but activities outside are being restricted as the fire continues to emit a huge plume of smoke that can be seen for miles.

Fox 11 in Los Angeles says Angels outfielder Mike Trout reportedly reaches an agreement on the largest contract in North American professional sports history. The 12 year deal is said to be, get this, worth $432 million.

And this is a live look at Chicago from our affiliate at Fox 32. One of the big stories there tonight. The Illinois Supreme Court lets stand the prison sentence for a white Chicago police officer convicted of killing a black teenager.

Critics say the sentence of less than seven years for Jason Van Dyke is too lenient, he was convicted of second-degree murder and 16 accounts of aggravated battery in the death of Laquan McDonald in 2014.

That's tonight's live look outside the Beltway from SPECIAL REPORT. We'll be right back to the White House after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: A look at the entrance to the West Wing right there.

President Trump is nominating former Delta Airlines executive Steve Dixon to head the Federal Aviation Administration, the FAA. Dixon is a former Air Force fighter pilot, is qualified to fly five different models of commercial jets, and was Delta's vice president of flight operations.

Now overseas, senior U.S. Defense officials say five ISIS fighters captured by the Syrian Democratic Forces may not be responsible for the bombing deaths of four Americans in January. An earlier report suggested the fighters were the main perpetrators.

Now a Fox News exclusive, we take you to the front lines in the last stand for ISIS in Syria. Correspondent Benjamin Hall reports tonight from eastern Syria.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BENJAMIN HALL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: A message from above. U.S. airpower is pounding what little remains of ISIS. Fox News has been given exclusive access to the front lines, embedded with U.S. backed Syrian Democratic forces in the town of Baghouz. It is the last corner of the last village of the caliphate and the final offensive is underway.

We are trying to push forward at the moment to get a better view of the clashes down below but there is an active sniper, we are having to take cover behind this tent (ph). This filthy tent city is all that is left of their so-called Islamic state but they are not done yet.

The camp sits on top of a warren of tunnels, some thought to be over a mile long, hundreds more surrendered today. everyone has stopped trying to guess how many remain.

Six weeks ago, the SDF said 1,500. Since then 30,000 have limped out and many more may still be hiding underground.

These guys are out here trying to pick off the ISIS fighters one at a time. It's slow going.

Despite the intense firepower, the U.S.-led coalition is being careful. They know there are women and children inside. While the women are now all considered fighters who carry out suicide attacks, the children are civilians presumed innocent.

Some reports suggest the fighters are being ordered to surrender, they know full well that they will be treated humanely, put into camps, able to live and fight another day.

But for those who choose to remain, the ones who want to die for Allah the bombing continues night and day. Be it today or tomorrow, the caliphate is finished.

In Baghouz, Syria -- Benjamin Hall, Fox News.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BAIER: More from Benjamin's reporting in Syria later this week.

Up next, it turns out the special counsel has been going after President Trump's former fixer and attorney for a lot longer than we thought. We'll tell you why.

First, beyond our borders tonight.

Dutch police say they've arrested another man in connection with yesterday's deadly shooting on a crowded tram. Three people were killed and several wounded. Authorities arrested one man a few hours after the attack. Prosecutors say they're investigating whether the shootings were terror related.

Mozambique's president says there are more than 200 people dead from the effects of the worst cyclone to hit that country in 20 years. He's declared three days of mourning. Aid workers say rapidly rising floodwaters have created an inland ocean endangering hundreds of thousands of people.

The British government is preparing to ask the European Union in the meantime for a delay of at least several months to its planned exit from the alliance. The Speaker of the House of Commons has ruled Prime Minister Theresa May cannot keep asking lawmakers to vote on the same divorce deal they have already rejected twice.

We'll follow Brexit as well.

Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight.

We'll be right back to the White House.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: Welcome back to the White House.

We are learning new information about just how long the Special Counsel has been investigating the President's former lawyer and fixer.

Chief intelligence correspondent Catherine Herridge is here with details on the probe into Michael Cohen.

Good evening, Catherine.

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Bret -- good evening.

The heavily-redacted court records show the investigation into Michael Cohen began nearly a year before the FBI raided his New York business and dwellings in April, 2018. The Special Counsel requested and obtained multiple warrants for Cohen's emails that covered correspondence during the presidential campaign. The filing runs into the hundreds of pages and 19 are completely blacked out or redacted with the heading, quote, "Illegal campaign contribution scheme," underlying how the president's greatest legal exposure may be in the Southern District of New York and totally unrelated to Russia collusion.

Cohen pled guilty to lying to Congress as well as multiple financial crimes, including campaign finance violations after two women were paid to remain silent about alleged affairs prior to the presidential election. President Trump denies their allegations. The unsealed records show federal investigators also wanted Cohen's historical and future location data for his iPhones to confirm from where he sent and received emails.

In April, 2018, the FBI sought and obtained authority to use an electronic technique known as triggerfish. On FOX today a former Justice Department official said the investigative strategy is not common.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JAMES TRUSTY, IFRAH LAW: I think it's probably geolocation, and knowing where this guy is, which could mean that they are trying to corroborate him on an important point, or it could mean they are trying to find out if he's lying to them about an important point.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HERRIDGE: The April, 2018, timeframe may be significant because Cohen testified last month that he was told by the U.S. attorney not to discuss his conversations after the FBI raid, Bret.

BAIER: Catherine, thank you.

HERRIDGE: You're welcome.

BAIER: Florida prosecutors have offered a plea deal to New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft and other men charged for paying for illicit sex at a massage parlor. The Palm Beach state attorney's office says it has offered Kraft and 24 other men charged with soliciting prostitution the standard diversion program presented to first time offenders. The men must concede they would be found guilty, perform 100 hours of community service, attend a class on the dangers of prostitution, and pay $5,000 per count. There's no comment yet from Kraft or his attorney.

Tens of thousands of migrant families from Central America continue to try to get into the U.S. at the southern border. National correspondent William La Jeunesse shows us tonight it is a situation that is overwhelming an already overworked Border Patrol.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIAM LA JEUNESSE, FOX NEWS NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: As the fight over the president's border policy continues, crews outside San Diego just completed a 14-mile steel fence and started a second one, stretching from the mountains to the ocean.

RODNEY SCOTT, SAN DIEGO BORDER PATROL CHIEF: This last year we've seen about a 700 percent increase in families and a significant increase in unaccompanied minors here in just San Diego.

LA JEUNESSE: This weekend 52 migrants rushed through a hole in the old fence. They tried to evade agents, then claimed asylum when caught. Unlike Mexicans who are quickly deported, Central Americans take hours to process to verify country of origin, travel documents, medical condition, and available bed space.

SCOTT: Between 25, up to 40 percent of agents are assigned nonpatrol duties today, processing, transport, or care and feeding of the family units.

REV. JANINE SCHENONE, SAN DIEGO RAPID RESPONSE NETWORK: We are seeing increasing medical problems as they come across the border.

LA JEUNESSE: Smugglers also use children as decoys, dropping off this six or nine-year-old over a fence while 10 migrants crossed illegally only a mile away.

SCOTT: We have to identify and then go apprehend every single person that crosses the border, whether they are claiming asylum, whether they're smuggling narcotics, or whether they're involved in human trafficking.

LA JEUNESSE: In a recent 73-day period DHS released 84,000 immigrant families back into the United States. In San Diego, nonprofits opened their own shelter to help ICE handle the overflow.

SCHENONE It has been a nonstop flow of people from anywhere from 50 to 140 people a day.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

LA JEUNESSE: The border fence stretched more than 650 miles when the president took office. He has replaced about 140 miles with this new style fence but wants at least 200 miles more either from the Defense Department or the 2020 budget. Bret?

BAIER: William La Jeunesse along the border. William, thank you.

So is Brazil ready to join NATO? President Trump thinks it might be, plus the other news the president made today here at the White House. We'll talk about that with the panel when we return.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I also intend to designate Brazil as a major non-NATO ally, or even possibly, if you start thinking about it, maybe a NATO ally. I have to talk to a lot of people, but may be a NATO ally, which will greatly advance security and cooperation between our countries.

JAIR BOLSONARO, BRAZILIAN PRESIDENT (through translator): Brazil and the United States stand side by side in their efforts to ensure liberty and respect to traditional family lifestyles, respect to God, our creator, against the gender ideology or the politically correct attitudes, and against fake news.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Well, the Brazilian president and the American presidency see eye to eye. They clearly established a relationship today, before today, and in the Rose Garden talked to reporters. Their main conversation, we are told, behind closed doors here at the White House was about Venezuela, and the president addressed a question about why it's taking so long for the disputed president, Maduro, to give up power.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I'm not being told any specific time. They have been there a long time, between him and his predecessor. At some point I would imagine things will change. But we really haven't done the really tough sanctions yet. We can do the tough sanctions, and all options are open, so we may be doing that. But we haven't done the toughest of sanctions, as you know. We've done, I would say, right down the middle.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Let's bring in our panel, Byron York, chief political correspondent for the "Washington Examiner," Amy Walter, national editor for the "Cook Political Report," and Matthew Continetti, editor in chief of the "Washington Free Beacon." Byron, your thoughts on this meeting and this exchange between the Brazilian president and President Trump.

BRYON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": I think the president may have adlibbed a little bit about making Brazil a full NATO ally because late this afternoon, three or four hours after this press conference, John Bolton, the national security advisor, tweeted that we are proud to make Brazil a major non-NATO ally. But other than that, really, Venezuela was the big deal, and the president made it clear that he felt there was a lot more that the United States could do, because the question really was, what you have been doing isn't working. Maduro is still there, what are you going to do? And he really made it clear that he feels there's a lot more the United States can still do.

BAIER: Amy?

AMY WALTER, NATIONAL EDITOR, "COOK POLITICAL REPORT": Right. And the question is, what is on the table for what the White House can still do, what the U.S. can still do, whether it is sanctions or whether there is more on the table is really unclear at this point.

I do think the fact the president spent time with someone who sees eye to eye with him on the way in which the world works, in the way in which they see government working or not working, the idea that there is fake news, this was a chance for the president to show that he has allies around the world who are willing to stand side-by-side with him in a part of the world that continues to be very difficult.

BAIER: Yes, and what was interesting is they talked a lot about space and the prospect of launching U.S. spacecraft in the future, Matthew, from Brazil, that possibly countering China's getting into Latin America with a deal with Argentina.

MONICA CROWLEY, COLUMNIST, "THE WASHINGTON TIMES": That's right, an important statement for one of the most interesting and most important relationships I think in the world today, Bret. And Bolsonaro, following Trump's lead, they both represent a new model of leadership for democracies, and that is they are both nationalists, they're both anti-elitist, they're both socially conservative, and you can tell by Bolsonaro's rhetoric that his voters are very similar to many of Trump's voters in what they care about and what they believe.

And they are also capitalists. And so socialism became an issue in this press conference as well. Trump once again framing the 2020 debate in terms of socialism versus capitalism. This is an argument that Bolsonaro can understand as well as Trump.

BAIER: And the press conference in the Rose Garden, it's kind of a two and two for reporters from both sides. The president was asked about social media and the efforts that he had talked about previously about banning conservatives. There is this lawsuit by Representative Devin Nunes against Twitter. There are other complaints against Facebook and others. Here's his answer.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I will tell you, there is collusion with respect to that, because something has to be going on. And when you get to the back scene, back office statements made by executives of the various companies and you see the level of, in many cases, hatred they have for a certain group of people that happen to be in power, that happen to have won the election, it's very, very fair to say that we have to do something about it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: That's a follow-up to a tweet, Amy, where he tweeted out "Facebook, Google, and Twitter, not to mention the corrupt media, are sooo on the side of the radical left Democrats. But fear not, we will win anyway, just like we did before! #MAGA." The issue of social media and these big tech giants seems to be an issue for both sides.

WALTER: I was just going to say that, Bret. For once you now see the president and Democrats, including very liberal Democrats like Elizabeth Warren, agreeing on the monopolization of power by these big tech organizations. You already had a lot of Democrats upset with what they saw was a hands-off approach by Facebook, by Google to Russian interference in the 2016 election. Elizabeth Warren now out saying we need to break up these big tech companies. And this was the place, Silicon Valley continues to be a place where a lot of Democratic fundraising comes from, where a lot of the Democratic operatives come from, and yet it no longer has that same shine, shininess, to Democrats, at least Democratic presidential candidates, as it once did.

BAIER: And Byron, on the flipside for Republicans who are usually against regulations, it seems like there is a growing chorus about doing something about tech giants.

YORK: There is, and this is really odd. Obviously, this a president who loves Twitter, it's been extremely important in his campaign and his presidency. I think he once said it was like buying "The New York Times" without any debt. It was just a great way to communicate with voters. But he actually supports this Devin Nunes lawsuit. The reaction on the left has been to laugh at the Nunes lawsuit, but a lot of conservatives do believe that some of the big social media companies use algorithms and other technical ways to suppress some of their ideas. And I think the Nunes lawsuit, maybe its biggest benefit would be to try to shake some information loose about whether that actually happens or not.

BAIER: All right, panel, stand by. Next up, Democratic presidential contenders want to make some big changes to the country, but do you? Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BETO O'ROURKE, (D) PRESIDENT CANDIDATE: What if there were five justices selected by Democrats, five justices selected by Republicans, and those 10 then pick five more justices independent of those who chose the first 10. I think that's an idea we should explore.

PETE BUTTIGIEG, (D) PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: It's not just about throwing more justices on the court. What I think we need to do is some kind of structural reform that makes the court less political.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If they can't catch up through the ballot box by winning an election, they want to try doing it in a different way. Now, we would have no interest in that whatsoever. It will never happen. It won't happen, I guarantee it won't happen for six years.

(END VIDEO CLIP).

BAIER: President Trump in the Rose Garden here at the White House answering a question about increasing the number of justices on the Supreme Court. It is a talking point now for a number of candidates as you look at the list here. Several of them are now talking openly on the campaign trail about Supreme Court reform, as it's called. They talk about it differently, but all say adding more justices in one way or another is something they would consider or want to do. But "The Washington Post" has a piece about Senator Michael Bennet, Democrat from Colorado considering getting in the race, "slammed his head on the table four times when I asked him what he thought about other Democratic presidential contenders embracing the idea of expanding the Supreme Court. Having seen up close just how cynical and how vicious the Tea Party guys and the Freedom Caucus guys and Mitch McConnell had been, the last thing I want to do is be those guys, he said during an interview at a coffee shop."

We'll start there with the 2020. Back with the panel. Amy, is this catching on?

WALTER: It is really fascinating, Bret, how much process has become part of the Democratic debate within the Democratic presidential candidates, within that field. It's not just the Supreme Court. It's also getting rid of the Electoral College, which is gaining a lot of steam. A number of candidates, including Elizabeth Warren last night, coming out in favor of abolishing of the Electoral College. Getting what of the filibuster, something the president talks a lot about. There are a lot of liberal Democrats who believe that's the only way if a Democrat becomes president to see a progressive agenda come through. You have to get rid of the filibuster. Adding the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico as states.

The feeling overall from a lot of Democrats, not just activists, but now people who are running for president is feeling that for years Democrats have played by the rules, Republicans haven't. And they have lost opportunities where Republicans have taken them, and they pointed specifically, of course, to Merrick Garland and the decision not to hold hearings on Merrick Garland. They say we know Michelle Obama told us in the 2016 campaign when they go low, we go high. Well, maybe going high isn't working anymore. So let's not do it.

BAIER: Matthew, you look at all of these things. You look at abolishing the Electoral College. You look at adding more Supreme Court justices. You look at reducing the voting age to 16. They all fit obviously a beneficial to Democrats in voting overall.

CONTINETTI: That's right. And the Democratic argument isn't with any single one of these things. It's not only with the Electoral College, it's not only with the 26th Amendment, it's not only with the state of the Supreme Court, it's not only with equal representation of small states in the United States Senate. The Democratic argument, Bret, is with the Constitution of the United States of America.

And the argument is because the left cannot win its arguments when they present them publicly. So in order to win, they need to change the structure. You heard Mayor Buttigieg right there say, the structural change necessary. What structure are they changing? They are changing the Constitution of the United States whose structure is there to preserve individual liberty. Barack Obama said he was audacious. This is audacity.

BAIER: Byron, Elizabeth Warren made that case about the Electoral College last night, we played the soundbite earlier, saying that every vote needs to count. But Lindsey Graham makes the opposite in a tweet, saying "The desire to abolish the Electoral College is driven by the idea Democrats want rural America to go away politically." And the focus being on the big states that have the most population, and the Iowas and New Hampshires and even the middle of the country would get less say, really.

YORK: Yes, what they'd really plan to do is the end run around the Electoral College. They realize they can't change the constitution, so there is a plan that if enough states whose electoral votes total 270 agreed to give their electors to whoever won the popular vote, then that would do it. They're not there yet, so this is not really close to happening.

But it would change our politics completely. Candidates would spend a lot of time trying to run up the score in California. Democrats would, Republicans would try to do the same in Texas. The Electoral College requires a majority of delegates. A popular election would just require a winner. There doesn't have to be two political parties, there could be a lot of different candidates and a plurality candidate could win. Playing with our constitutional order is a really dangerous thing.

BAIER: Amy, just to get back to what you said at the beginning, the process being such a focus. As one candidate talks about it, it seems like they all start to talk about it. And when you have the over/under being 20 voices talking about the same process things, does that hurt Democrats on the trail?

WALTER: I think they are meeting the activists where they are and the base where the base is. And again, I'm sure all of us here around the table have been in and around politics long enough that we have heard arguments both for and against the Electoral College for a long time, but it never really made its way up to the people that were running for president or potentially could be president. Now it's actually getting a hearing. It's unclear about how long that's going to stay there.

One other interesting point, though. The debate over the Electoral College isn't new, and it's not always on one side of the other. Back in 2004, 54 percent of Republicans wanted to get rid of the Electoral College, wanted to see a popular vote winner. And now, says Gallup, that number is down to 19 percent.

BAIER: We'll follow it. Maybe we'll get to some substance on policy, too. Thank you, guys. Thanks, panel. When we come back, a special surprise for a karate kid.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BAIER: A gorgeous night here at the White House. Finally tonight, a surprise for one karate kid.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Daddy?

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Staff Sergeant Rob Cesternino surprised his nine-year-old son Luca during martial arts class Monday at Lebanon, Tennessee. He was wearing a blindfold. He didn't think his dad would be home until the following week. Rob and Luca were both given honorary belts at karate class, and that is just an awesome moment. Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. I could play those all day long. That's it for the SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced and unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Martha starts right now.

END

EMILY COMPAGNO, FOX NEWS HOST: Yes. So this father was deployed for ten months. He came home and he surprised his son in Tennessee.

Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You are such a big boy. I am so proud of you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST: That is so sweet, indeed.

All right. Set your . Never miss an episode of THE FIVE.

"SPECIAL REPORT" is up next. Hey, Bret.

BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Hey, Dana.

Sometimes I feel man slapped but it's OK.

President Trump says the worst may be yet to come for Venezuela's embattled and disputed government.

Democrats are proposing big changes for the U.S. Supreme Court, the Electoral College, and the nation's voting age.

And we take you for an exclusive look at the front lines in Syria as U.S.- backed forces engage ISIS in the terror group's last stand.

This is SPECIAL REPORT.

Good evening. I'm Bret Baier. We're coming to you live tonight from the White House where I will talk with one of the president's top economic advisors in just a few minutes.

We begin though with President Trump saying all options are still on the table in the effort to remove Venezuela's disputed president and his socialist government. The American leader saying here in the rose garden even stronger sanctions may be coming. He spoke with reporters this afternoon alongside the visiting Brazilian president.

Chief White House correspondent John Roberts was there. Good evening, John.

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: Good evening -- Bret. And a lovely afternoon in the rose garden it was.

So far the effort to oust Venezuelan dictator Nicolas Maduro has been unsuccessful. There had been some cracks in his regime but so far none big enough to wedge him out.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: Venezuela was Topic A in President Trump's first meeting with the new Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro. President Trump indicating he has no idea when Nicolas Maduro may step down if ever.

TRUMP: I'm not being told any specific time but we really haven't done the really tough sanctions yet, we can do the tough sanctions and all options are open.

ROBERTS: Brazil shares a border with Venezuela and has been assisting the U.S. in getting humanitarian aid to Venezuelans fleeing economic collapse. Bolsonaro indicated he may allow U.S. troops to base out of Brazil if the need for military action arises.

JAIR BOLSONARO, BRAZILIAN PRESIDENT (through translator): Brazil would be more than willing and ready to fulfill this mission and take freedom and democracy to that country.

ROBERTS: In welcoming Bolsonaro to the White House President Trump was almost looking in the mirror. Bolsonaro is known as the Trump of the Tropics. He has the same views as the President on immigration, uses Twitter as a megaphone --

BOLSONARO: fake news.

ROBERTS: -- and decries fake news.

TRUMP: we're going to have a fantastic working relationship. We have many views that are similar.

ROBERTS: Bolsonaro also represents a break from a long line of anti-U.S. leaders promising a new relationship with America on everything from trade to energy to military cooperation. President Trump is happy to embrace the change.

TRUMP: I also intend to designate Brazil as a major non-NATO ally or even possibly, if you start thinking about it, may be a NATO ally which will greatly advance security and cooperation between our countries.

ROBERTS: In the Oval Office prior to their joint press appearance, President Trump was asked about his weekend Twitter feud with Meghan McCain after President Trump ripped her father for giving the FBI the unverified Steele dossier.

The President was unapologetic pointing to McCain's vote against repealing and replacing Obamacare.

TRUMP: So he campaigned, he told us hours before that he was going to repeal and replace and then for some reason, I think I understand the reason, he ended up going thumbs up. I think that's disgraceful. I was never a fan of John McCain and I never will be.

ROBERTS: President Trump also weighed in on Twitter and Facebook today after his director of social media was temporarily blocked on Facebook and Republican Congressman Devin Nunes filed a $250 million lawsuit against Twitter.

TRUMP: It seems to be if they're conservative. If they're Republicans, if they are in a certain group, that is discrimination, a big discrimination. I do think we have to get to the bottom of it.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ROBERTS: President Trump also used Bolsonaro's visit to take a swing at the emerging socialist movement in the Democratic Party here. Bolsonaro won the presidency in Brazil by campaigning against the socialist corruption that had led to Brazil's economic decline. President Trump repeated his mantra that the U.S. economy is stronger than ever and that the last thing we need is socialism -- Bret.

BAIER: Thanks -- John.

Let's get some insight on the U.S. economy and the President's big plans from the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisors, Kevin Hassett. Kevin -- thanks for being here.

KEVIN HASSETT, WHITE HOUSE COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISORS: It's good to be here.

BAIER: Your overview first of all this report just out, you seem kind of ecstatic but --

M1: Yes. I'm always ecstatic.

BAIER: -- behind that.

M1: Right. Well, I think that basically what we've done is we published a book with 700 pages that documents President Trump's policies are working, that the economy has gone from the new normal of low growth to the old normal of 3 percent growth, that it's doing it precisely because the policies are working the way economists think they should.

So we said a year ago in the fall that capital spending would working, the economy has gone from a new normal of low growth to the old normal of 3 percent growth and it's doing it precisely because the policies are working the way economists think they should.

And so we said a year ago in the fall that capitol spending would boom and that factories have come back to America. We documented that that is happening in the data.

We said when the factories would come back, that people would be hired more and so unemployment rate went down to historic lows for just about every category rate -- democratic category. And we said that wages would grow a lot because the people at the factories would be competing for workers and we see that as well.

And the most striking thing on that, you know, I promise not to filibuster is the bottom 10 percent of Americans saw wage growth last year of 6.5 percent.

BAIER: JPMorgan in their forecast for 2019 said this. "Significant U.S. economic outperformance is unlikely to persist through 2019 as the sugar rush of the fiscal stimulus wanes."

M1: Yes. So a lot of people said that we wouldn't have a sugar rush and now they're calling it a sugar rush, but it's not a sugar rush. So a sugar rush again --

(CROSSTALKING)

M1: People should we are having a sugar rush but it's not a sugar rush. People should go to a Disney. It's even like a that admits that sugar does that to you. But in any case if we ate at twinkie and a bunch of twinkies and spent all our money on twinkies. The next would bad and we wouldn't have any money and we'd be sorry when we did that.

What happened now is that we didn't, you know eat Twinkies. We took vitamins and we made the economy stronger exercise and it's stronger from now on.

And so people built more factories last year, that made the GDP go up because they're buying machines. This year though, factories are turning on and they're going to make output and that's going to make GDP go up again. So it's the opposite of a sugar rush.

BAIER: For the folks who are critical about the next steps -- like what are the next steps this administration will take to try to push that growth forward?

BAIER: Amy, just to get back to what you said at the beginning, the process being such a focus. As one candidate talks about it, it seems like they all start to talk about it. And when you have the over/under being 20 voices talking about the same process things, does that hurt Democrats on the trail?

WALTER: I think they are meeting the activists where they are and the base where the base is. And again, I'm sure all of us here around the table have been in and around politics long enough that we have heard arguments both for and against the Electoral College for a long time, but it never really made its way up to the people that were running for president or potentially could be president. Now it's actually getting a hearing. It's unclear about how long that's going to stay there.

One other interesting point, though. The debate over the Electoral College isn't new, and it's not always on one side of the other. Back in 2004, 54 percent of Republicans wanted to get rid of the Electoral College, wanted to see a popular vote winner. And now, says Gallup, that number is down to 19 percent.

BAIER: We'll follow it. Maybe we'll get to some substance on policy, too. Thank you, guys. Thanks, panel. When we come back, a special surprise for a karate kid.

BAIER: A gorgeous night here at the White House. Finally tonight, a surprise for one karate kid.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Daddy?

(LAUGHTER)

(APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BAIER: Staff Sergeant Rob Cesternino surprised his nine-year-old son Luca during martial arts class Monday at Lebanon, Tennessee. He was wearing a blindfold. He didn't think his dad would be home until the following week. Rob and Luca were both given honorary belts at karate class, and that is just an awesome moment. Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. I could play those all day long. That's it for the SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced and unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Martha starts right now.
